In the velocity selector, the ions experience an electric force Fe = qE and a magnetic force Fm = q(v × B).
For ions to pass through undeflected, the net force is zero, i.e., Fe + Fm = 0.
The electric field E is directed vertically upwards, and the magnetic field B is directed outward perpendicular to the plane of the paper.
Let the horizontal velocity of the ions be v.
Assuming the ions move horizontally to the right, and E is upwards, B is outward.
For positively charged ions (q>0), Fe is upwards.
Using the right-hand rule, if v is to the right and B is outward, v × B is downwards, so Fm is downwards.
For undeflected motion, the magnitudes of the forces must be equal: Fe = Fm, so |q|E = |q|vB.
Since q ≠ 0, E = vB, which gives v = E/B.
If the ions were negatively charged (q<0), Fe would be downwards, and v × B would be downwards, so Fm would be upwards.
Thus, for any non-zero charge, undeflected motion requires the magnitudes of the electric and magnetic forces to be equal, leading to v = E/B.
The charge-to-mass ratio of the ions selected by the magnetic analyzer.
The ions enter the magnetic analyzer with velocity v and move in a uniform magnetic field B directed outward.
The magnetic force provides the centripetal force for the circular motion.
The magnitude of the magnetic force is Fm = |q|vB.
The centripetal force is Fc = mv^2/R, where R is the radius of the circular path.
|q|vB = mv^2/R.
Since v ≠ 0, we can divide by v to get |q|B = mv/R, so |q|/m = v/RB.
From the velocity selector, we know v = E/B.
